I give it a 5 star with these changes.  I only used 1 - 8 oz. cream cheese, 1/4 c. butter, and 2 c. powdered sugar, 1 1/2 tsp. vanilla.  It covered a 9 x 13 carrot cake perfectly.

text:
Note:

You need to know that this cream cheese frosting is for the person that wants a REAL cream cheese taste, as if they were eating actual cheesecake. This is not a sweet, sweet, sugary frosting. This is a cream cheese blessing! Not the kind you find in the container in the grocery store. This is homemade, amazingly delicious, cream cheese frosting!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Oh my goodness, this is a simple and yummy recipe and only took 15 minutes in my mixer.  Make sure you start with room tempurature or softened butter and cream cheese.  It will make your life a million times easier.  I also followed the advice of the previous reviewers and added an extra 1 cup of sifted confectioners sugar because we like our frosting sweet.  I also doubled the vanilla extract for a more intense flavor.  I had no problems with the consistancy whatsoever.  Since my husband likes the white frosting and I like chocolate, this batch made enough so I could divide it up into 2 separate batches.  I just took out 1/2 of the batch and set it aside.  Then I added 1/3 cup of pure cocoa powder (not hot chocolate mix) to the remaining batch and mixed it some more.  We each frosted our own 1-layer 9" separate cakes and it was delicious both ways!  If you only have 1 cake, you might want to reduce the recipe by half.  Enjoy!

text:
Great recipe!  I used a slightly different method:  beat softened cream cheese with vanilla until smooth, then add softened butter a little at time, beating until smooth.  Finally, add powdered sugar to taste (I usually use less than called for).  I found this method to give the best consistency.  I've used this frosting on sam's carrot cake and pumpkin gingerbread (both from this site) with great results!

None
text:
This recipe has both an unusually high proportion of cheese and low proportion of sugar (IMO). I like the resulting flavor, but it isn’t for everyone. For a less 'in your face' cheese flavor, I halve the cream cheese (8 oz instead of 16),  add 1/4 cup of butter, and one more cup of powdered sugar. The final thickness tends to vary on several factors (brand/type/temperature of the cheese and butter) so I add milk/powdered-sugar to give me the 'spreadability' I want. I use this as a 'base' recipe for frosting many baked items, changing thickness and flavoring to suit my current use. It isn’t a decorator frosting for the real fancy stuff, but it isn’t meant to be.

text:
It was the lesser amount of butter and sugar that made me curious to try this recipe over what I've been making since forever. I don't know how this would have held up on a layer cake as it would definitely need to be firmed up in the refrigerator first, but let me tell you, it was awesome on the carrot bars I made today, and would be great on any sheet-type cake.  Just lightly sweet and perfectly cream cheesy. Each recipe has its place, and I will make this again for any kind of bar or sheet cake needing a cream cheese frosting. Thanks for sharing your recipe Janni!

text:
Perfect frosting - exactly what I was looking for! I used this on a bundt carrot cake from a box, and it really made it special. I sieved the confectioners sugar to avoid lumps, and added it slowly, tasting at intervals until I was happy with the sweetness.  I also used kahlua (about 3 teaspoons) to flavor, which is sweet, so I cut back on the amount of sugar used.  I frosted all sides of the bundt cake and have plenty left over - my boyfriend was eating the icing with a spoon!  Thank you for the great recipe!

None
text:
Important!!!  Guys, unlike regular sugar, powdered sugar acts like a curve in this recipe; it will make this recipe (and many others) MORE LIQUIDY the more you add. Once it is liquidy, you have to add a whole lot of sugar (or flour) to get it hard again. Weird, I know, but true. This is why people who are complaining about the consistency usually claim to have added a bit more sugar to it. If you want your consistency to be harder, then just add a bit less sugar, not more! Stop short of turning runny!!!  That been said, it is not a sweet frosting... more like cheesecake flavor, which is perfect for me and many people out there. I stopped adding sugar half a cup before the required amount and everything turned out perfect... not too sweet, very cheesy, and it will be awesome on my carrot cake.

I made two batches, one as directed which turned out too soft to pipe onto cupcakes. The second, I first whipped the butter and sugar well, then added the COLD cream cheese a piece at a time. The result was a delicious, thick pipeable cream cheese frosting. This method is the key!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This frosting is excellent and I use it quite often now on different cakes, with small variations. Our family has a sweet tooth so the 2 cups of sugar don't really cut it for us, the frosting seems to taste more like cream cheese with that amount of sugar in. Therefore, I add one extra cup of sugar (so 3 cups instead of 2) and the frosting comes out just perfect for our taste! When we need chocolate frosting I simply add coco powder until I get the right taste and color.  I noticed that the consistency of this frosting depends very much on the cheese cream I use. I made this using Philadelphia cream cheese and the consistency was pretty good, I was able to decorate my cake with it (see my photo gallery). However, where we live, this brand is pretty expensive, so at one time, I tried a generic supermarket brand instead. The same frosting, with the same quantities of cheese, butter and sugar came out pretty runny, no way to decorate with it. It was fine for us because we had no guests coming over, so we ate the cake the way it was. But if I need this frosting to look good, I use more expensive brands and it turns out great. This is a no fail, super tasty and incredibly fast to make frosting and I highly recommend it. Just keep in mind that it is not stiff enough for any fancy cake decorating.

city:

country:
None
text:
I use a very similar recipe - except I only use 8 oz cream cheese, 1/4 cup butter, 1/2 cup more sugar, and a generous teaspoon of vanilla (can also use almond for a pleasantly different taste, if desired).  Turns out creamy and not toothachingly sweet - so you actually get to enjoy the flavors of the item being frosted.  Typically I used it for carrot cake, but I've also used this to top homemade cinnamon buns.

For those who complain about it being too thin - try refrigerating it for 30 minutes to an hour... it should firm up a bit.  Also, the cake (especially if frosting a two-layer cake) MUST be entirely cooled - otherwise the warmth from the cake will cause the frosting to *thin/melt*.  Using these tips, I've never had any problems!

userID:

Display Name:
rosabela

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is probably the best frosting on this site! I made the chocolate version for the Black Magic Cake found on this site and added the full 1/2 cup of cocoa as suggested by the author. It was rich and decadent. I made and extra half recipe but since I ran out of cream cheese, I made the same recipe with mascarpone. The frosting turned out a bit grainy but tasted very decadent. I used it as the filling and piped rosettes with the cream cheese frosting. I'm still a novice when it comes to making frosting, but this time around I found that by using an electric mixer will whip more air into the frosting making it fluffy and spreadable/pipeable. I initially stirred the frosting with a wooden spoon and it had turned into a soupy mess. Rather than adding more confectioners' sugar, I then decided to whip it with the electric mixer and it did the trick. I also found that the longer you whip it (say, several minutes) the fluffier it becomes. I also found that it's best to let the butter come to room temp. by letting it sit on the counter for a while. I had originally softened it in the mircrowave only to have little butter flecks in the frosting. I let the batter sit for a while, rewhipped it again, and the butter flecks were gone. This is definitely the only frosting recipe that I will use in the future! Thanks for sharing this wonderful recipe, Janni!

text:
Best cream cheese frosting I have made! My husband couldn't stop piping it into his mouth! I did have one person tell me that there was too mush vanilla but I don't think so. I added crushed glazed pecans that I made myself. I melted 2 cups sugar and 1/4 tsp salt on the stove and tossed the pecans in it. I transferred it to wax paper and when they cooled I crushed them in a plastic bag with a rolling pin and then mixed them into the frosting. YUMMY!!

text:
Loved it with the few minor changes based on a review below: 1 block of softened cream cheese, 1/4 cup of butter, 1&1/2 cups sifted powdered sugar and 1 tsp vanilla extract. Preparation followed the original recipe. I only needed it to frost 2 dozen cupcakes and I did have about 1/3 cup left over. (Guess where that went?!) Tip for those of you having a problem with consistency: After preparing your frosting, refrigerate it for about a half an hour before stirring it and then spreading it over your baked good(s). If you need it to keep its form after that, you will have to refrigerate your frosted product. If it is too thick, let is stand at room temp before frosting. Good luck and happy baking!

text:
This is the first time that I've rated a recipe this low.  I tried to make this frosting to go on my 9 year old daughter's birthday cake. It was a disaster! I was so happy that my cake came out beautiful...until I whipped up a batch of this frosting. I followed the recipe exactly as it is and I came out with something that resembled a cheesy sweet soup.  It tasted good, but nothing could save the texture. And I mean NOTHING. I tried adding more sugar, more butter, leaving it to firm in the fridge, mixing it more, mixing it less, etc. As a last resort, I added a bit of flour.  Only then was it firm enough not to slide right off the cake! But it still didn't come close to the firmness needed for piping or decoration. I ended up spreading it all over the cake, hoping it wouldn't melt right off, and getting out my trusty cake decorating gels to make it somewhat presentable. This would taste good on a cake if you planned on leaving it in the pan until you served it. Other than that, I was very disappointed with this recipe. I hope my daughter will still like her birthday cake.

I hate to review a recipe based on the modifications I've made but I figured I should share the changes to help others out.

I've never made this as is because reviewers said it comes out "too cream cheese-y" So here are the changes that make it sooo perfect:
use 1 8oz cream cheese, 1/4 c. butter, and 2 c. powdered sugar, 1 1/2 tsp. vanilla.

userID:
10847843
Display Name:
kearyc

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/962153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was amazing on carrot cupcakes and so quick and simple to make! Other than halving the recipe, I didn't change a thing. I love it because it's a true cream cheese flavor and it's not disgustingly sweet. I let my cream cheese and butter sit out to soften. At first my frosting wasn't very firm (I noticed that my frosting got thinner and thinner as mixed, either from the heat of the room or the heat and friction from mixing), but I chilled the frosting for a couple hours while my cupcakes finished baking and cooling and the texture was just perfect for spreading. 

If your frosting is coming out a little thin, my advice is: 
1. Don't microwave your butter or cream cheese to soften- let it soften at room temp. 
2. Don't over-mix it or take too long, as it'll get a little warmth in it and thin out. 
3. Stop adding all that sugar to firm up your frosting! It's an unnecessary frustration, it over-sweetens this perfectly balanced frosting, and did I mention calories yet? Just pop your frosting in the fridge for a while and walk away.

text:
This is the BEST cream cheese frosting that I have ever made - and I have tried countless recipes looking for the perfect one.  This is the real deal in terms of cream cheese taste.  I made it exactly as it was written, and I wouldn’t change a thing.  I generously frosted a 13x9 and I still have more than a cup leftover (thinking of frosting a pumpkin bread with it!).  The sweetness is perfect - at least for our tastes.  On a side note….I’ve seen some of the pictures posted on this recipe, and I definitely suggest that you chill the frosting thoroughly before you try piping it onto cupcakes or cakes.  The heat generated from beating the frosting makes it less than ideal for using immediately if you’re planning on piping with it.  And of course - any cake frosted with it should remain refrigerated.  Enjoy! :)

text:
I'm glad I tasted this frosting before putting it on the cakes.  The amount of cream cheese is WAY too much.  I doubled the rest of the ingredients, using 2 packages of cream cheese, 1 cup of butter, 4 cups of powdered sugar, and 2 tsp of vanilla, and then the frosting tasted perfect.  This frosting colored very nicely with Wilton's gel icing colors for writing on the cakes.  I did need to thicken it a bit to be able to pipe a shell border, but even with the extra-extra powdered sugar, the flavor was still nicely tangy.  I'll definitely use this recipe again, reducing the cream cheese amount by half.

text:
The best cream cheese frosting I've ever tasted. Just like what you'd find on carrot cake at a very expensive restaurant. Consistancy is PERFECT, so easy to spread and frost. If you're having difficulties (too runny) make sure your butter is only slightly softened, FAR from melted or even margarine-like in consistency. I'll use nothing but this from now on!

text:
This recipe was excellent. It didn't specify the type of butter so I used unsalted and added a pinch of salt. I also sifted the powdered sugar first. The first time I made it, I accidentally used half the butter listed but otherwise followed the recipe exactly. The second time I made it, I used the correct amount of butter and found that I preferred it w/ less butter. I also thought this was pretty sweet so def. wouldn't add more sugar. I did need to refrigerate the frosting cause it got a little runny when warm. But it was simply divine on a red velvet cake. Highly recommended!

None
text:
As written this frosting recipe would be great on a sheet cake or layer cake. When frosting cupcakes, I use a large star tip and like to get height with my frosting, and I found this to be a little too thin to hold up to those demands. By increasing the sugar to 2.5 cups I got the perfect fluffy consistency for frosting my red velvet cupcakes. I love that this cream cheese frosting actually tastes like cream cheese! :o)

text:
Just like my grandma makes!  Perfect cream cheese frosting every time.  Tip: If you want to use this to frost cupcakes bakery-style, add lots more powdered sugar until it's more stiff so that it can set.  Otherwise, it will look droopy on your cupcakes.  To balance out the sweetness, add a pinch of salt as you mix in the extra powdered sugar.

It tastes like slightly sweetened cream cheese.  Maybe good for frosting other things, but not a cake. I should've used that one or something in between.

I didn't need much, so I cut the recipe in half, but didn't change the ingredients. INCREDIBLE. I cannot wait to try this on many, many things. I just put some on pumpkin cookies. However, the consistency was perfect for cake decorating (I want to try it!) - I did soften the butter first, creamed it with the powdered sugar and vanilla, and then beat in the cream cheese in cold chunks. Great tip! I seriously felt like I was eating cheesecake and could not resist eating spoonfuls. Thank you!

text:
This is the only cream cheese frosting recipe I use now! I have been making it for about a year, and usually only make 1/2 the recipe. Most of the time I just do the recipe exactly as written, but I have occasionally varied it successfully by adding things like cocoa, or lemon extract, or maple syrup/extract, or toasted coconut with coconut cream. Best as is, but still makes a great base for these other flavors as mentioned. Super easy and yummy!

text:
Very delicious! After reading a few other reviews about it not being sweet enough, I had planned to add three cups of sugar but tasted it after two cups and found that it was perfect, plenty sweet - and believe me I like things sweet! Made this in my Kitchen Aid stand mixer and it came together wonderfully. Used it frost Carrot Cake XI from this site. The only almost-problem I had with it is that it doesn't make as much frosting as I thought it would (I know it says 3 cups but it's hard to imagine whether that's enough or not). I had just enough to fill and frost two 8-inch layers with a fairly thin layer of frosting - not enough left over to pipe borders.

text:
I loved this but I love cream cheese and I don't like overly sweet frostings.  I made it exactly as written.  I used it to frost my daugher's birthday cake and she and her friends loved it, too, even though both of her friends said they usually don't like frosting.  This frosting is VERY SOFT.  I would not try to frost a layer cake with it.  I made my cake in a 9x13 pan because, after reading the reviews, I knew it would be soft.  It also does not harden at all, even after being refrigerated overnight.  If you are looking for a sickly-sweet grocery store-type frosting, keep looking.  If you want a great cream cheese frosting, use this one.

text:
If you are looking to frost a cake stop and start over.  This is not the frosting for you.  I love cream cheese, cheesecake, and I like the flavor of this frosting BUT it's really reminiscent of cheesecake batter.  It's just too much and it's the kind of thing you only want a lick of (like cheesecake batter).  In addition to that the frosting is TOO RUNNY!  It was horrible.  I should have known it was too much cream cheese and not enough powdered sugar, I should have read the reviews.   The description specifically states it can be used for chocolate cake but unless you're baking in a 9x13 dish and have the edges of the dish to hold in the frosting, I would highly suggest finding another recipe more suitable.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674140.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this icing, I've made it several times and it is always a delight.  I do use confectioners sugar rather than regular sugar but that is the only change I make.  I would like to address an issue that may be the problem for some who have made this and had a problem with it not being stiff enough.  You must use Heavy cream, not whipping cream.  There is a difference between the two.  Heavy cream or it may be called heavy whipping cream has more butter fat in it, at least 36% and hopefully 40% or more.  It is that extra butter fat in the cream that makes good whipped cream for desserts.  Another thing that I do when whipping the cream is put a bowl inside of a larger bowl into which I have put ice.  That keeps the bowl very cold when whipping the cream. Whip the cream until stiff peaks form, but does not taste buttery. It won't take long.  Then whip the cream cheese sugar mixture, while the whipped cream is still sitting in the bowl that is sitting on the ice.  After whipping the cream cheese, lighten it up with a large spoonful of the whipped cream before folding in the rest of the whipped cream.

text:
This is incredibly delicious, and my husband says it's the best frosting he has ever had.  I used it on Sam's Famous Carrot Cake (recipe on this site), and it was just perfect.  It was easy to spread,  and I had plenty to frost a 2 layer round cake.  I have no idea what those who complain about a soupy or runny texture did when they made it. My husband and I both loved it, and we see no need for any modifications.  Thanks for giving us such a wonderful recipe! :)

text:
This is a great recipe if you like a really cream cheesy flavor. My husband, who isn't really into icing loved it because it wasn't too sweet. I did; however, find another recipe for cream cheese icing that is much better for cake decorating. I was looking for a recipe that I could ice a cake a lay fondant over. For a more firm and even tastier version of this add a 1/2 cup of shortening, 1 tsp salt and use the entire 2LB bag of confectioners sugar. You won't regret it!!

Used this frosting on Sam's Famous Carrot Cake. We think the recipe is fine if wanting a powerful cream cheesy flavor but a bit over the top for us by drowning out the flavor of the carrot cake. Used Publix brand regular cream cheese and experienced no problems as some indicated would happen if not using a name brand like ‘Philadelphia’. The frosting had a nice consistency, and easy to spread. I would not hesitate to use this recipe again but would only use 1 (8 ounce) package cream cheese just as a good number of reviewers said they do.

text:
Amazing! Perfectly tangy and rich. I've gotten slightly fluffier results when I whip the butter, sugar and vanilla together first, then add the butter/sugar mix to thoroughly beaten cream cheese.  [Note: You really need to use the classic 'brick' style cream cheese. Not the loose, spreadable stuff you put on your bagels. There's far too much water in it, and your frosting will be soup.]

Made two batches, the first one came out too liquidy, I think the butter and/or cream cheese was too warm when mixing. I'm giving this 2 stars only because it really does taste great, HOWEVER.. frosting IS supposed to stay on a cake! I've never made cream cheese frosting before now, but I will definitely be trying another recipe next time. If you are just going to frost a sheet cake, this may work better for you, but you are trying to do a layered cake like I did, you may want to keep searching.

text:
Absolutely delicious! No changes necessary! It is very cream cheesy, but this is the way I like it, so if you do like your cream cheese icing more sweet, you might add more sugar. I added a tad bit more vanilla, just because I like vanilla. =) Also try adding other flavor extracts for a change (like orange. :) 
I used this for carrot cake and a good tip that my boyfriend really liked was sprinkling heath bar bits (you can buy them in a bag next to the chocolate chips in the cooking aisle) over the top of the icing.

text:
This is a great recipe! As other reviewers have said, it's the real deal.

I accidentaly made the following adjustments:
1.  Once, I made it with 4 c sugar, which yielded a stiffer frosting (which I liked), without sacrificing the cream cheese tang.
2. I also once made it with 1 package cream cheese and 3 c sugar...also good.  Not quite as tangy as with 2 pkgs cream cheese (no brainer).

In other words, you really can't mess this up, no matter what you do with this recipe!

text:
I don't typically review on here since I tend to forget too, but I almost had to make sure to leave one for this. Amazing frosting and super easy! I would consider myself an average cook and my baking is NOT my specialty. Go by the book on this recipe! I tried taking the advice of adding an extra cup of sugar, and I did not like it as much. I tried it before hand and thought mmmm absolutely delicious but then decided to see if it was possible to make even better with more sugar. I only added 1/4 maybe 1/2 extra cup of sugar but had preferred it beforehand. It didn't ruin the frosting by any means, I just personally LOVE real tasting cream cheese frosting and not the SUPER sweet frosting. Either way I am so proud I was able to make the best tasting frosting I've had in a loooooooong time.

text:
I thought that I'd clear up some of the problems people were having before about the frosting being too runny. If you melt the butter completely, this recipe will not work. It just needs to be room temperature. In fact, I let the butter and the cream cheese sit out for about 10 minutes on top of the oven while the cake was cooking and it came out to be the perfect consistency. So much better than store bought, I will probably never buy canned frosting again. Amazing and highly recommended!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This frosting is perfection if you love cream cheese. If you like a super sweet, really stiff frosting, then this might not be your thing. I let my butter and cream cheese sit out on the counter all evening while I prepared other recipes. Of note, I used one regular cream cheese and one neufchatel - wonderful results. By the time I was ready to make frosting, everything was super soft and easy to mix. Took about 5 minutes in my stand mixer. I did increase my powdered sugar to about 2-1/2 or 3 cups, just until I got the consistency I wanted. The taste is out of this world. I believe anyone who enjoys cream cheese frosting will like this recipe - if you want a little different flavor, all you need to do is tweak it a bit - but the basic foundation is here. Great recipe!

This is one of the best cream cheese frostings I have tasted. The characteristics I like the most are the fluffiness and the fact that it is not sickeningly sweet. I did add an additional teaspoon of vanilla, but other than that I prepared the recipe as written. This is perfect for the person who does not like super sweet frosting and loves cream cheese. The frosting is subtle enough to let the cake be the star but delicious enough to stand alone. Why mess with perfection? I will use this whenever I need a cream cheese frosting!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/819236.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As I was only frosting a bundt cake ("One Bowl Chocolate Cake III"; which is really Hershey's Deep Dark Chocolate Cake recipe that I've been making for years), I halved this cream cheese frosting recipe. I didn't add vanilla, per the suggestion of one reviewer, besides, I didn't have clear vanilla and really wanted the frosting to come out strikingly white. This recipe does not seem to taste "overly cream cheesey." And it is not overly sweet. I find that this is a happy balance between rich and subtle. If you like strong cream cheese flavor, add more, if you like sweet, add more powdered sugar. This recipe does make a lot and I'm glad I halved the recipe. I also added some milk to thin the frosting down a little, as I wanted the frosting to be a little thin to slide down the edges of the bundt cake a bit. This frosting recipe as written will yield a thick enough product to beautifully frost just as in the picture submitted my Janni. Love this recipe and will definately be using it in the future. Thanks for the submission.

text:
An excellent cream cheese frosting recipe. I kept the cream cheese refrigerated until I was ready to use it and I took the butter out about 30 minutes prior, so it was in between refrigerated and room temp. I blended the two ingredients together until smooth and then added the vanilla and confectioners' sugar. I had an eager crowd waiting for the Chocolate cupcakes (recipe also from this site), I had made to be frosted so I wasn't able to let the frosting sit in the fridge for a while before using. I will next time and also might try sifting the confectioners' sugar and pipe the frosting onto the cupcakes. Overall...very happy with the outcome.

country:
None
text:
I wanted a fluffier cream cheese frosting than I thought this would give me, so I modified the amount of cream cheese and butter in the recipe. Instead of two 8-ounce bricks of cream cheese, I used one 8-ounce package of cream cheese. Instead of 1/2 cup butter, I used 1 cup butter. I kept the amount of confectioner's sugar the same, but, because I prefer a whammy of vanilla flavor, I upped that to about 2 teaspoons of vanilla extract.  Of course, it is essential that the butter and cream cheese are softened to room temperature for maximum fluffiness! I was really happy with the results, which were probably sweeter than the original and no doubt had a bit less cream cheese taste but more of a buttercream mouth feel.

This recipe was very tasty, but I had to add an additional 2 cups of confectionary sugar in order to receive the correct consistancy, which resulted in there being WAY too much frosting for a 9" x 13" carrot cake. The next time I make this frosting, I will half everything EXCEPT the confectionary sugar.  (The cream cheese taste was very strong as well.) Overall, very good, will make again with the said changes.

text:
Very good basic cream cheese frosting recipe.  I followed the recipe exactly and it came out perfectly.   This is certianly tangier than canned frosting, but that's what makes it so good.  If you think it's too tangy, just add more powdered sugar.  I really can't see how this recipe can turn out runny being that the only liquid called for in the recipe is a tiny bit of vanilla.  I think that the problem could be that some people used melted butter rather than softened butter and that certianly would make the frosting runny. By the way, half of this recipe covers a 9x13 cake generously.

None
text:
I was looking for a frosting to compliment my chocolate ganache and lingonberry infused chocolate cupcakes and decided that a cream cheese frosting may work well. Prior to making this recipe, I browsed recommendations by other reviewers and made the following modifications: I used 1-8 oz. cream cheese, 1/4 cup butter, 2 cups powdered sugar, and 1.5 tsp. vanilla. 

As with all frostings, you can modify the consistency and sweetness of the frosting by adding or subtracting powdered sugar; thus, I recommend adding powdered sugar gradually (divided, in two or more moments) to ensure that your frosting does not become too thick or sweet.

text:
Strong cream cheese flavor may not be everybody's cup of tea, but this is exactly how I like my cream cheese icing.  I made a half batch with neufchatel (since that's what we had on hand) and sucralose (because sugar and I don't get along so well); the flavor is bang on.  

Just one note: a full sized batch of this recipe is probably about right for icing a two-layer cake.  A half batch should be plenty if you're icing 12 standard-sized cupcakes.  I still have some left over.

This was  great recipe! I love cream cheese frosting; the only problem for me is that some cream cheese frostings can tend to be a little grainy. This recipe was wonderfully smooth; and I didn't even use an electric mixer! Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:

userID:
1811559
Display Name:
TinkRNone

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/823178.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We found this frosting to be heavenly! Great flavor and consistency. Yes, it was very loose and creamy at first (not what I would call runny though), but that worked out great for the initial application to my cake. Had I had time to refrigerate each of the 3 layers with the frosting on top for a few minutes before assembling, I don't think it would need stabilizing with a bamboo skewer through the middle of the 3 layers, though this worked really well.
I placed what was left in a glass bowl in the freezer for about 10-15 minutes to firm up while I placed the iced cake in the refrigerator. The firmed frosting worked great in my piping bag for the finishing touches.
I made 1 1/2 recipes as I was frosting a large three-layer cake (Sam's Famous Carrot Cake from this site.) 
Ended up having a little frosting left over, but it's in the freezer for later use. I did add about 1/2-3/4 tsp extra vanilla (to this larger portion) as some other posters had suggested. This frosting apparently accepts color well also according to all the photos posted. 
Our family and friends devoured the dessert like they had never had cake before - all the while ooo-ing and awww-ing. Will be using this recipe time and again! Thanks for posting, Janni.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2013-10-05T18:46:50.067
helpfulCount:
2
userID:
4197247
Display Name:
Betty Crocker
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
140
favoritesCount:
564
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love a good cream cheese frosting but I'm sorry, I definitely tweaked it. I used 4 oz of softened cream cheese, about 6 oz of softened butter, 3 huge tbsp. of corn syrup and a good splash of vanilla extract.  Mixed until well blended and light in texture.  Added icing sugar 1/2 cup  at a time until I thought I had enough to frost my cake. If needed, add a tsp of milk or cream to frosting to blend.  If too soft, just add a little more icing sugar until you get the consistency you wish for frosting your cake.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a simple and delicious icing. Success with this recipe depends on the consistency of the the cream cheese and butter.  The butter needs to be soft not melted. The cream cheese must be the regular cream cheese not the light or whipped cream cheese. Cream cheese should not be too soft when mixed.  I leave out of refrigerator unwrapped in the bowl with the unwrapped butter for about an hour. Then I cream them together with the mixer.  I use this icing to frost soft sugar cookies and dip them in ground nuts. The icing mixture requires refrigeration if at room temperature for more than an hour or so depending on room temperature.

text:
I used this recipe to frost cupcakes and it tasted pretty good, but I had some trouble with it looking separated/streaky once I added color to it.  It was also a little thin for piping to start with, but I was able to thicken it up a little with extra powdered sugar (although then it got a little sweeter than I would've liked).  I will try this one again, but next time i'll make sure i'm more careful about bringing the butter and cream cheese to room temp first.  Also, I didn't sift my powdered sugar this time, and that may be why I got streaks.  I think i'll also try mixing the cream cheese until smooth and then adding the butter a little at a time.

Really easy to make. I followed the other suggestions and only used one 8 oz package of cream cheese and upped the icing sugar to 3 cups. It was pretty runny when I finished mixing it so I put it in the fridge for a couple of hours and it firmed up. 

The resulting icing was a little sweet for my taste, but I served it between two gingerbread cookies to my husband (who has a real sweet tooth) and he could not get enough!

country:

text:
I'm so glad I chose this recipe for my daughter's first birthday cake.  It was delicious and the whole family loved it.  I made it exactly as written.  

A few notes:
-I doubled the recipe to frost and decorate a 12" round cake and even then I barely had enough.
-The consistency was just right for piping decorations.  Next time I might thin some of it just slightly for more spreadable icing.
-I think I didn't let the butter warm up enough.  I had flecks of butter that jammed in my decorator tips as I was piping.  As a total newbie cake decorator it was frustrating, but probably totally my fault.

I'll definitely use this recipe again!

text:
The perfect frosting! (& I normally HATE frosting!) This is very full of cream cheese flavor, and not too sweet tho still plenty sweet. The only adjustments I make is more vanilla & sometimes we add the smallest bit of cool whip to make it fluffier. but I dont change it much. My family loves it on any kind of baked good but we use it most on our unique cranberry salad for thanksgivings and on our pumpkin bars for halloween. We are huge pumpkin bar fans & have made them every year just about & we always use this frosting for them! BEST on the site. Cant be beat! (NEVER buy the store bought kind when you can make this... the store stuff is just GROSS once you have tried this!)

text:
I only needed half so I halved the ingredients to suit my needs.  This frosting is perfection.  It's not like creamed sugar, you can actually taste the cream cheese.  I doubt I'll buy the can again unless I'm crunched for time (although, this took all of 10 minutes and I used cream cheese and butter straight from the fridge!)  I will also say that the reason I only needed half was because I didn't realize that I would need more than one can of the store bought.  So for consistancy's sake, I made my own, then dumped in the can...A completely new taste and experience.

text:
I made this a second time and I find the best way to make this is 1st leave the cream cheese and butter out until they are room temperature, 2nd beat the butter 1st by itself until it is nice and smooth and creamy than add the cream cheese gradually. I found the mixture at the end to be a lot smoother, and fluffier, my family LOVED it. Perfect for red velvet cupcakes

This is my first rating and I just had to chime in.  This is the best cream cheese frosting I have ever had.  I've had frosting from professional bakers and this rivals any of them.  AND, it's super easy to make.  As other reviewers have stated, it makes ALOT.  I (thick) frosted an entire sheet cake (9x13) and still had enough left to frost an entire other one.  Either halve the recipe or store it for future use.  Delicious and now my go-to cream cheese frosting recipe!

text:
i didn't read each of the 2000 reviews, so someone else may have noticed this already.... but this is the exact recipe for the libby's pumpkin roll cream cheese filling.  that said, it doesn't have the texture that makes me think of "frosting".  it's very smooth but thin, and would be difficult to pipe.  i used it to frost black forest cupcakes and it worked well as i was just frosting them flat across the top to cover in cherries.  the taste is phenomenal...a zillion stars if i could.  but i don't consider this a frosting and wouldn't use it generally to frost cakes.  maybe to fill layer cakes...but i think it's best used as a filling.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe exactly as written and used it to frost Red Velvet Cake I from this site. This frosting is very good, but VERY INTENSE. It is like eating a piece of cheesecake. I absolutely love the fact that it isn't very sweet because my family hates sweet frostings. But because it isn't light and fluffy (when cold from the fridge it is actually more dense than a cheesecake), a little goes a very long way. The recipe made way too much for 2 9-inch layer cakes - we were all practically sick from the icing off 1 normal sized piece of cake! That said, I will definitely make this recipe again (maybe a half-recipe) and use SPARINGLY on carrot cupcakes because in small doses it is delicious!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
If your looking for a recipe like a store bought can frosting, this is it. However, I honestly can say I wasn't. The flavor was excellent, smooth and creamy. However, It was way to soft for what I was looking for. I followed the recipe to the T but it never thickened to the point where it was stiff pipedable as I thought it would be. Now if I had thought about it at the time when I made it. I would have refrigerated the batch over night the frig to get the thick frosting I needed for the recipe I was using it with. But didn't think about it until I was reviewing it after being angished for it not setting up in my cake preparation. But then I realize. I used butter. Butter is softer in frosting and doesn't hold up like shortening based frostings. This recipe is not a "sit on our countertop and leave out" type of recipe. It's totally a make and store in the frig and would make great for a cupcake filling because it has a really good flavor. And if I was looking to do so, I'd make this again for that reason. But just wasn't what I expected I'm sorry.

Wow! I, too, don't like really, really sweet frostings. I made this recipe using lower-fat cream cheese (neufchatel), and it's still unbelievably good. I think you can tweak this lots of ways and it will still be good. I can't BELIEVE how good. Yum! Thank you, Janni! (Lots of people are adding more sugar, but this was certainly sweet enough--maybe even still a little too sweet for me, but I haven't tried it on the cake yet--I've been licking off the spoon--over and over again, by the way, it's so good. :-)) There's plenty plus some left over for a 9 x 13 sheet cake, so it's okay to sample it. :-) By the way, I am an absolute amateur at baking and cooking, so I really appreciate the simplicity on top of the scrumptiousness of this recipe.

text:
In order to be able to spread the icing on a cake without it leaking everywhere, I had to use 6 C. Icing Sugar & 1 Tbsp. Flour, instead of the 2 C. recommended.  Lovely taste...but there's a big difference between 2 C. & 6 C. of Icing Sugar...so I only gave it 3 stars.  It's a 5 star with the changes-and refrigerate before using.

text:
This is the best cream cheese frosting that I've made or tasted. If you're looking for the sugary frosting with only a hint of cream cheese (like many of the store-bought frostings) this is not the same. This is sweet but not very sweet and it has a strong cream cheese taste. This is the best frosting to use for an authentic carrot cake. Thanks for submitting this recipe; it's absolutely wonderful. I wish I could give this more than 5 stars. Be careful, though, you will be tempted to eat this straight out of the bowl!

text:
I love the light texture and tangy taste of this frosting. It looked fantastic piped high on my cupcakes and was a great compliment to the chocolate flavour. A warning to those who prefer a sweeter, less intense cream cheese icing -- the cream cheese is definitely the dominant flavour. I (and the majority of the people who sampled it) thought it was fantastic, but a handful of my taste-testing guinea pigs thought the flavour was too strong.

None
text:
This is my favorite cream cheese frosting--the one I use every time whether I need it for a red velvet wedding cake or a carrot cake for Easter. It is thick enough to withstand layering without oozing out the sides and pipes well, unlike many other versions which don't have enough sugar and are too thin. This is perfect as written. If you want to keep it more on the whiter side, rather than ivory, use clear vanilla.

text:
I used this with a pumpkin cookie recipe I found on this site and it was delicious.  The consistency is wonderful--very creamy and smooth, but with some body.  It is a bit tangy-er than most frosting, but it was a perfect compliment to the pumpkin cookies.  I'd love to try it on chocolate cupcakes someday.  One downside:  it doesn't really set up (or it takes more than a day to do so, at any rate), so depending on where and how you are transporting the frosted piece, that could be a problem.

text:
Not what my son had in mind for his pumpkin cupcakes... as he said " there is way too much cream cheese flavor for kids", I had to double the other ingredients before it was more "acceptable" to him. Yes it was drippy after a while, I assume that is from the already softened butter being whipped fluffy and melting a bit more. Post-refrigeration it is much better. 

A double batch is more than enough for 60 cupcakes... I guess it is fine that there is so much left over, I like spreading it on pumpkin bread slices like jam...

EDIT: I find it tastes much better the next day... I have all that left over and it tastes much better than  yesterday!

This was the easiest to use consistancy of any frosting I've made.  I would suggest doubling the vanilla, but I liked the not-too-sweet flavor.  Creamy, fluffy, soft, not instant-headache sweet!

Great icing recipe!  I used this with the Carrot Cake XI recipe found on this site, to make a special cake for my family.  We all loved it.  My husband couldn't raved about how good the icing was, and proceeded to lick the bowl and spoon completely clean!  I might add a little bit more sugar next time, though, because it had a strong cream cheese taste.  I can see how other people who reviewed this recipe thought it was too runny:  I think they might have let the cream cheese and butter get too soft, and might have over-beat it when they were creaming them together.  It's a fine line between not creamy enough and too creamy, so be careful.  Mine came out a little soft, but I just put it in the fridge for a bit.  Otherwise, it was great and I'll most definately use it again!

text:
If anyone is having problems with this frosting being too soft or runny, it's probably because they are using soft margarine [in a tub], which has water in it [this is what keeps it soft, even when it's very cold]. To make this recipe have its best texture, use stick butter or margarine.

text:
Yum!  I made this frosting for banana bars.  I'm so confused as to why or how people are having a consistency problem with this recipe.  It's probably the easiest frosting recipe I've ever made.  Fully softened the cream cheese and butter, threw them in my kitchen aide bowl with the vanilla, let it mix using the whip attachment while I sifted the sugar.  Added the sugar, whipped it for about 3 minutes...DONE.  Spread perfectly on my banana bars that I baked in a 15x10 baking dish.  Plenty of frosting.  If you're looking for super sweet frosting where the sugar overpowers the cream cheese, this isn't it.  Delicious real cream cheese frosting that I ate with a spoon...holy moly!  I'm traveling with these banana bars so I put everything in the fridge to firm up before cutting.  They need to be pretty!  Can't wait to taste them!  UPDATE:  The banana bars were very good on their own.  This frosting is seriously the star of the show and made them DELICIOUS!!!  I thought they would be better cold.  I was wrong.  Room temperature, they were AMAZING!

This is a VERY runny product, it barely holds form.  I don't recommend it at all for a frosting. It's more like an icing.  Tried to use it on cupcakes and it was extremely disappointing.  Basically was a cupcake decorating failure.  And I followed the recipe exactly.  No user error, I've worked in a kitchen for years. text:
This was my first time making cream frosting and I incorporated the recipe revisions suggested in Pabbydog's review (8 oz. cream cheese, 1/4 c. butter, 2 c. powdered sugar, 1-1/2 tsp. vanilla).  I also used Neufchatel cheese rather than cream cheese.  It's definitely a WOW recipe that you can eat with less guilt than eating so much cream cheese.  This is a great, rich-tasting frosting that can be used on just about anything.  Highly recommend!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm not sure how the people who found it runny, went wrong.  It's an icing, not a frosting, but still!
-Use CREAM CHEESE, not CREAM, like someone must have, by their comment.
-Wait until your cake cools down before icing it, so it doesn't start to melt.  At room temperature, it spreads like butter or cream cheese, amazingly enough.
-It may seem obvious, but if you don't like the taste of cream cheese, don't use cream cheese to make icing.
I only used 2/3 cup of icing sugar because I want to taste the cheese, not the sugar, and it still stuck fine to my cakes--mind you, they had tapered sides from the tapered sided pans I used, so more traction.

text:
This was awesome. I ended up using 3 cups of  sugar tho for just a touch more sweetness and 1 1/2 tsp vanilla. If you end up with something runny the recipe is not the problem. Remember as you beat the icing you're warming it and butter will break down if it gets too warm. Unfortunately there isn't a way to fix it after that so if it looks like its getting too soft put it back in the fridge for a little bit or do it in a chilled metal bowl.

text:
This recipe was amazing!

I only used half of every ingredient because the given recipe would've made more servings than I needed. With that I frosted about a dozen and half mini red velvet cupcakes with some left over. 

I brought red velvet cupcakes with this frosting to my internship and people devoured it very quickly! They said the best part of this frosting is that it's not too sweet and it's the perfect texture. The only thing I would do differently from now on is add a little more vanilla extract to mask a little more of the cream cheese taste.

country:

text:
Very good.  I made this recipe as directed.  I put it in the fridge for a while before using and it spreads easily.  I made it a second time and used powdered vanilla (to avoid liquids making it any runnier) as well as 7% more (15 grams in my case) cream cheese than instructed (my portions come in 80gram blocks, so I went ahead and put in all 240 grams) and liked it even better.  Will use this recipe again and again.  The proportions, the ratio between cheese, butter and sugar, in my opinion are right on.  Not too sweet, not too savoury and doesn't cover up the taste of the cake it dresses.  My daughter described it as having a light and delicate cheesecake on top of her cupcakes.

text:
I made this today. It wasn't runny at all. Even though I added in 1/2 can of Solo apricot filling it wasn't runny. I did do as one poster mentioned and used my butter and cream cheese right out of the refrigerator. Maybe that is the difference between perfect frosting and runny frosting.

 It isn't cloyingly sweet either. Usually I scrape off the frosting and then eat he cake with a minimum of frosting. No need to do that with this frosting.

Other than the apricot filling I didn't make any changes to this recipe.

text:
I have this mixed up and in my fridge right now waiting for the cake to cool...now, like the review on January of '06, I eliminated one of the 8 OZ cream cheese after reading that it was more like icing and quite runny (another review that I read). However, even then, I still chose to add yet an extra cup of sugar.  I can remember making regular butter cream frosting throughout my life and always started with 2 c confectioners sugar to 1/4 c butter, so I knew that the extra volume in the form of cream cheese may well make the product runny.  It looks and tastes yummy and I look forward to it on the cake.

text:
I really loved the cream cheesy taste of this frosting. The flavor was great. If you want a sweeter version, just add a little more powdered sugar to your taste. The only problems I had with the frosting were of my own making, not the recipe's. I only had 1/3 fat cream cheese and while the flavors were still there, it never really got "sturdy" enough to pipe with any level of detail. It was pretty loose. I know that if I'd used real cream cheese, it would have been perfect. 

Because my error left mine a little thin, I did add more powdered sugar to see if it would thicken. It didn't help too much, but it did absorb a lot of sugar and still didn't seem too sweet. I'll definitely make this again but will use regular full fat cream cheese. YUM!

text:
This was PERFECT!!!  Yes, it's tangy and not too sweet -- and that's what I want in a cream cheese frosting.  I down-sized the recipe proportions to suit my needs and the amount of cream cheese I had (4 oz).  I pulled the cream cheese right out of the fridge and accidently melted the butter but it worked fine anyway.  I've used it on squash / walnut / Craisin muffins, and oatmeal / chocolate chip / molasses / walnut breakfast cookies, and I, too, have eaten it off the spoon.  Mine was not runny, and set up even more after refrigeration; it's still spreadable.  LOVE THIS!!!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/642330.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have used this recipe a few times now and love it!  Last night, however, I could relate to those of you who have experienced runny frosting.  I made this frosting ahead of time, and added an extra 1/4 cup butter so there would be more frosting in the end.  I refrigerated it for one day.  I let it soften a few minutes before mixing it again in the mixer.  It was runny so I tried adding extra sugar... no luck.  My advice is:  1.  Make this in a room temperature area.  If it seems warm at all, be careful of the temperature of your ingredients.  2.  Follow the recipe.  If you need more frosting, double the recipe, not just ingredients.  

This recipe is worth five stars if you make it the right way!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2013-09-26T16:15:56.147

text:
This tasted great. I was making this to put on top of the cinnamon rolls I mad for breakfast this morning and it tasted excellent. I made a few modifications though. I didn't really need that much frosting so I cut the cream cheese in half, using only one 8 ounce package. I maintained the 1/2 cup of butter, used 1 1/2 cup of powdered sugar, and had to forgo the vanilla because I forgot that I ran out. To make it a little thinner, I added a few tablespoons of milk to it. Came out great, but next time I may leave it at 1 cup or 1 1/4 cups of powdered sugar instead. I liked the distinct taste of the cream cheese without the overwhelming sweetness that many cream cheese frostings have.

text:
I will admit, I am one of those people that will scrape the frosting off of the cake and throw it in the garbage. But this frosting is fantastic. It will not make you sick with sweetness or eat away at your teeth because of the sugar. It is a mild sweetness and comes out thick and creamy. I only added about a 1/4 cup more of powdered sugar then it called for and followed the rest exactly. I was able to frost 2 9 inch round cakes with plenty left over to decorate the top. Yum!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The recipe is fairly easy and basic, it has a great cream cheese flavor and blended well.  However, the issue comes with the texture, creamy and delicious stand-alone does not translate well to a topping.  This must be kept cold, at room temp it is far too soft and doesn't hold shape. 
This recipe would be a perfect cupcake or pastry filling, in fact, I froze the leftovers for Christmas pastry fillings.  Even though it will make a five star filling, it's just a two star frosting. 

Pros: Great flavor, creamy texture, simple to prepare. 

Cons: consistency, texture, stability at room temp.

5

text:
This frosting is perfect for cupcakes, however, I needed this for a 2-layer cake and the icing seemed too sticky. I followed proportions for butter and cream cheese. Used 1.5 cups powdered sugar and 1.5 tsp vanilla. I read that decorator's icing has shortening, so I added 6 Tbsp of cubed  shortening. I have a scant cupful of frosting leftover from the cake to keep in the refrigerator, and use on cupcakes.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used this frosting to top "Sam's famous carrot cake."  The only thing I did differently was I added less powdered sugar. As the carrot cake was very sweet, I didn't want the frosting to take the whole thing over the top and into the too sweet range. So instead of adding the entire 2 cups, I added 1 cup, then gradually added the second cup bit by bit, tasting as I added. I ended up only using 1 1/2 cups of powdered sugar total. It made the frosting the perfect complement to the cake.

userID:
4898573
Display Name:
katespace

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm not sure why anyone is adding more sugar to this recipe - if you're looking for a sweeter frosting, you should probably reconsider using a cream cheese frosting recipe in the first place!

The frosting came out absolutely perfect, aside from some lumps of cream cheese because I was impatient in whipping the frosting.  My advice would be to whip the cream cheese and butter on high for about 20 minutes before adding the sugar to ensure the lumps are mixed in.

The sweetness to tartness ratio was absolutely perfect with the recipe as is.  The only modification I made was to use vanilla paste (includes vanilla seeds) instead of vanilla extract for the visual effect of the vanilla seeds in the frosting.

The consistency was great for spreading on the cake before refrigerating, and once the cake was frosted I put the whole thing in the fridge to harden up.

Would definitely make this again! :)
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2012-03-09T08:15:42.53

text:
Yum! The flavor is phenomenal!!! I loved this frosting, however as other reviewers mentioned, the frosting is not thick enough to pipe. 

Great if you are icing a sheet cake, but if you are icing a round cake, the icing will run unless altered to thicken.

Having said that, I still LOVED this flavor. The best cream cheese frosting I have had thusfar. Gave 4 out of 5 stars due to consistency.

I made a sugar-free version of this to go with my gluten-free, sugar-free cake, and it was GREAT! I used unsalted butter (the recipe doesn't specify), increased the vanilla to 2 teaspoons, and used 2.5 cups of splenda in place of the sugar. I'll be making this again! :)

text:
Thanks to PAPPYDOG, the frosting came out wonderful!  I'd followed PAPPYDOG'S suggestion of this recipe and it was plenty of frosting to cover 36 mini cupcakes, and had some left over in the bowl for my daughter...

I gave it a four because you really don't need 2 (8 ounces of cream cheese) unless you are covering a really big cake...

If you make this frosting you really need to be a big fan of cream cheese, for the flavor is really heavy cream cheese.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6359594.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a super-delicious icing but it definitely required a few minor modifications. First, in order to get the right consistency I had to use 2 cups of confectioner's sugar, not 1. Also, it was too sloppy to use without refrigerating it beforehand. Since I was using it in a piping bag (for frosting cupcakes) I ended up filling the piping bag, standing it upright in an empty juice pitcher and putting it in the fridge for about half an hour. It worked out well in the end... but there were a few stressful moments there.

This was amazing! I added about a cup more of icing sugar to get it to stiffen a little, and about 1/3 cup cocoa powder to make it more coherent with my cake. It didn't stiffen up as much as I'd have liked but it was still delicious.  I've never been fond of buttercream or whipped frosting but the touch of cream cheese worked wonders here. I paired it with Red Velvet Cupcakes (from this site) and they were a match made in heaven. Will definitely use this as a filling between cake layers!

Because it's not so sweet, the flavours really come through.

userID:
559890
Display Name:
SEBENE
isPro:
False
followersCount:
9
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
9
favoritesCount:
320
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2498742.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Amazing frosting.  I made it just as the recipe is written.  As one reviewer stated, this is a true cream cheese frosting, not that sweet junk you get out of the cans.

I would suggest using it with a sweeter cake or dessert in order to offset the less sweet frosting.  I used mine to top "Sam's Famous Carrot Cake" from this site and it was an amazing combination.

This frosting is not something I would suggest for cookies but it might make a great filling for something like whoopie pies.  I used my stand mixer for this so I may have just whipped it up too much, but the consistancy just doesn't seem right for something such as cookies or smaller more delicate type things.

Definitely a winner on carrot cake though!

5

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/398894.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is not screamingly sweet frosting. It is perfect with just enough sweetness to accompany, in my case, carrot cake. 
I had taken a tip on using some citrus in this recipe. The added citrus opened this recipe up: the pairing of neufchatel cheese (this is what I had used instead of cream cheese) and the lemon went hand in hand extremely well.  
Instead of using 1 teaspoon of vanilla extract, I used 1/2 tablespoon of the vanilla. I had also added 1 teaspoon of lemon zest, and 1 1/2 tablespoon of lemon juice. 
I had used this on the Sam's Famous Carrot Cake recipe, to which I had added a few other ingredients too. This frosting is wonderful alone, and especially on this cake!!!
6/17/2011: If you make this frosting alone to eat, you won't be disappointed! So, so good! :-)
Review:

I will tweak the amount of sugar I add depending on what I need to do with it in the future, but will definitly be using it again.

I hate to leave a bad review, but this recipe is waaaaay too tangy.  The proportion of cream cheese to powdered sugar is way off.  I increased the sugar to 4 cups and added a few teaspoons of milk, to make it a spreading consistency.  It was still not sweet enough for a true cream cheese frosting for a cake.

text:
I love the flavour of this frosting, but had difficulty with the consistency.  It came out rather runny for me.  However, there could be some extra factors as to why this happened.  First I used my hand blender, which I’ve never used for frosting in the past, I usually hand mix with a fork.  Secondly I already had on hand some spreadable light cream cheese so I used that.  As with other frostings I added more confectioner’s sugar, but it didn’t thicken up like I would have expected it to.  I will try this recipe again, just to see if it turns out better and update my review.

text:
I hate giving bad reviews, but I'm going to be honest. My guests liked this, but I will be using different measurements next time.  
I followed the recipe exactly and it ended up being extremely heavy, and thick with the cream cheese. A plus is that it wasn't overly sweet, so I felt I could add another cup of confectioner's sugar, which helped a little. I would suggest using half the cream cheese and maybe more confectioner's sugar. 
This might be good over cinnamon rolls, or as a dip for cinnamon sticks. I wouldn't suggest anyone use it over cake or cupcakes (what I made) because it was too heavy for the cake. I felt like I was eating a cream cheese pudding actually.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677176.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very easy and tastes great!  Here are some tips that would have helped me out when I first made this recipe:

- Before combining the cream cheese and butter, if both are room temperature, it'll save time.  I added my room temp. butter to creamcheese that was colder, and the mixture became very lumpy.  If your mixture looks lumpy, let it sit until it's room temperature.
- If you want a runnier mixture, if you mix it too much it separates a bit.
- If you want a thick consistency for decorating cakes/cupcakes, I added 1/2 cup more butter and added confectioner's 1/2 a cup at a time until it reached the consistency I wanted.  For the last batch I made I added an extra 4 cups.  I didn't have to worry about separating with the thicker consistency.

text:
Delicious! I also used half the cream cheese and butter (as many others suggested) as well as an extra 1/2 tsp of vanilla extract.  Make sure the cream cheese is softened to room temperature before creaming it with the butter. If it isn't , a quick trip to the microwave for 10 second increments will solve the problem.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow. Awesome flavor. My whole family loved it. I used this frosting for pumpkin spice mini cupcakes. I first made it just as the recipe said and it was perfect for my taste - just a bit tangy (I did add cinnamon to taste). But I wanted it more like a thick buttercream consistency for piping on the cupcakes so I did add another 3/4 cup of sugar. The consistency was still a bit too soft and I honestly preferred it before adding the extra sugar. Oh well. Next time I will keep it as written. And to those who think it should be sweeter and that's why they add more sugar - just remember. If you wanted a sweet frosting there is always buttercream - cream cheese frosting isn't meant to be so sweet. I will continue to use this recipe again and again! Thanks!

This is the best Cream Cheese Frosting I have found yet!  Although I have given it a 5 star rating, there is one thing that I change.  I really love a bold cream cheese flavor, so I usually start with only 1 cup of sugar instead of 2.  I then add more to taste, but I never put a full 2 cups in the frosting.  Usually for a full cake, I double the recipe as well.  I also love how easy it is to make!!!!

text:
As much as I love cream cheese, this recipe is too rich for certain desserts such as light and moist pumpkin cupcakes. I would only recommend using a recipe like this w/a very dense cookie or cake. The butter is a nice touch, but 1/2 the cream cheese would have been sufficient. Sometimes less is more. I think if I ever make this frosting again, I'm only going to use a 1/2 stick of butter as well.

text:
As everybody else is saying, this is a fantastic and really easy to make recipe. I personally think adding an extra cup of confectioner's sugar is a little much, but if that's what does it for you, then okay. I followed the recipe and got a wonderfully sweet and tangy frosting. A trick to help get the cream cheese and butter started, besides just having them both softened, is adding a dash of milk or cream - it makes it all a lot easier.  I used this on top of a German-style Apple Cake, and topped it with homemade caramel. This frosting really helped make the cake. Thanks for posting!

text:
I made some alterations. I used 1/4 cup of butter as suggested by another reviewer, and I used more 3 8-oz packets of cream cheese because I made a 3-layer chocolate cake for my daughter's birthday celebration. I also made another alteration. I used only 1 cup of the powdered sugar, because I added sweetened coconut as an additional topping/garnish, and I did not need the additional cup of sugar. My mother brought a 'professional' cake from the bakery where she lives, and everyone left the 'professional' baked cake and  reached for my cake. Thanks for sharing this wonderful frosting recipe with us!!!

I tried this recipe because I was looking for a frosting that wasn't too sweet.  It was very good and had a nice smooth consistency.  It was, however, very heavy on the cream cheese(not a bad thing!) and didn't have that typical fluffy texture one expects in a frosting.  Maybe more of the sugar would have helped?  I used this to frost a 9x13 cake and there was plenty.  I wouldn't however, use this for cupcakes...I think it was a little too soft.

I could eat spoon-fulls of this frosting!  Some reviewers were saying to only use 8 oz instead of 16 oz of cream cheese, so I split the difference. Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/807603.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used this recipe on some regular mix cupcakes and it turned them into something fantastic! I halved the recipe because I didn't have enough cupcakes to need the full amount, in fact I would say this recipe makes a lot more frosting than you need, at least for cupcakes.
First, let me say I had absolutely NO problem with the consistency. I used softened cream cheese and beat in the vanilla, then added the softened butter in small amounts, though I used slightly less butter than the recipe calls for. Then I added the sugar a little at a time. As soon as the first 1/4 cup was mixed in, it looked like perfect frosting, with a thick consistency and a shiny texture. I added as much sugar as it needed to get the taste I was going for - for my halved version, it was somewhere around 3/4 cup.
And it only took a couple minutes to make! I'll definitely use this again. 5 stars!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A great cream cheese frosting.  It had a wonderful taste and was just what I was looking for to put on my pumpkin cookies. I will add that the texture is very soft. It was perfect for frosting my cookies but it would be hard to frost the sides of a cake and expect it to say in place, but it would be good if you out it on a sheet cake or between layers. It is so soft you could dip cupcake into it to frost them, and much easier. NOTE: This frosting stays soft and sticky, it does not crust over.  You could also add extra sugar to make it thicker.  Plus to add, I ran out of Powdered sugar as I was making this so I put 1 C. of granulated sugar into my coffee grinder and ground it to a fine powder. It worked perfectly and I didn't have to run to the store for one cup of powdered sugar. :-) It would not do this for a lot of powdered sugar but for this small amount it worked well.

region:

country:
None
text:
After reading the reviews, I used 8 ounces of cream cheese, 1/4 cup of butter, 2 cups of confectioners' sugar, and 1 1/2 teaspoons of vanilla.  This produced the perfect amount to frost two dozen cupcakes.  The flavor of the frosting was excellent, but I found it to be a little runny.  But overall, it was a good recipe.

This is a great frosting but it did have a very strong cream cheese taste and I tend to like frostings more sweet. I had halved the recipe b/c I only made one round cake, after mixing and taste tasting added another cup of powdered sugar to sweeten it up... but very good recipe all the same... just depends on what you like! I hate using the store bought icings/cake mixes b/c of all the  they use in them so this was a nice find. I used this with Dark Chocolate Cake I and it turned out well. Lots of compliments. Thanks for the good recipe.

text:
The consistency varies each time I make it. I think it has to do with the amount of beating that takes place. I beat the cheese with vanilla first until smooth as RALWATTAR suggested and it helps with any clumping of cheese. I also add more powdered sugar for chocolate cakes and less for carrot or bar type cakes. I've only used it on a sheet cake and cupcakes so I don't know how this "thinner" consistency icing would fair on that. Thanks so much for sharing such a delicious and versatile icing! I just LOVE the cream cheese taste!!

Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2007-03-30T21:09:49.803
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
2295881
Display Name:
SarahS
isPro:
False
followersCount:
9
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
41
favoritesCount:
20
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/413590.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I cut the recipe down a bit since I was only frosting a small single layer cake.  However, I ended up adjusting it so much in order to get the desired consistancy that I had way more than I needed anyway.  The frosting tasted great though so I'm happy that I have some for later use, since I froze what was left over.  This is one of those recipes where you don't have to worry about being so exact with the measurements because you just adjust it to the way you like it and to suit whatever you are serving it with, by adding more or less of certain ingredients (which in this case, is basically the confectioners sugar).  This frosting was much softer than I expected (no matter what I did to it) so dont expect to pipe with it.  If you want to decorate with it, I would suggest using whipped cream cheese frosting as that would be much easier to work with.

By the way, I used a light cream cheese, which I highly recommend.  There's a stick of butter in this frosting so youre not sacrificing any taste by using a reduced fat version or even neufachatel. (I dont think theres that big of a taste difference between the 2 cream cheeses anyway)
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
Great frosting!  I just used it for some red velvet cupcakes.  This recipe generously frosts 24 cupcakes.

I added about 1/2c more of the sugar as I was mixing, as well as 1T more vanilla for a more intense vanilla flavor.

Follow up:  I think this frosting keeps better if you store your frosted item in a cooler place, like a cool pantry or fridge.  I left mine out in the kitchen and the butter in the frosting seems to make it melt a bit if it's warm.

text:
A good frosting for the size carrot cake I baked (Best Ever Carrot Cake by Nan). But I had to add at least a cup or two more sugar (okay more like 3!) to get it to the consistency I needed (a carrot cake isn't finished without decorating it with frosting carrots!) I also added a little sour cream to give the frosting more of a tangy flavor. I would suggest playing around with this recipe to get it just right for whatever cake one chooses. Thanks for the submitting this recipe!

This was just ok in my opinion.  I followed the instructions perfectly.  The frosting came out runny.  It tastes good.  I believe it has too much cream cheese in it.  When I try this again I will 12 oz of cream cheese instead of 16 oz.  Also, I did NOT MELT the butter and cream cheese, I softened it.  I also, put the frosting in the refrigerator for an hour before I used it.  It warmed up quickly and was runny.

I don't know if I'll be making this again, because this recipe is TOOOO GOOD! Anyway, I had tons left over, and it kept calling my name from the fridge, my kids kept finding me sneaking spoonfuls of it! text:
Wonderful, creamy, delicious, and easy-to-spread frosting that got raves from all who tasted it.

I increased the powdered sugar by about a cup to give it a little sweeter flavor (doing so didn't make it too thick to spread).  I took part of the frosting, stirred in some lemon juice to taste, and used that as filling for the layers.

Will definitely put this recipe in my "keepers" file!  Thanks, Janni!

userID:
26653369
Display Name:
Mandi Irving
isPro:

followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7434333.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Enjoyed this recipe! Was really concerned about the reviews regarding consistency but it was no issue! I took a few tips from other reviewers. I used "softened" cream cheese ( full fat) and butter (REAL salted butter). Left out for approx 90 mins. Soft but still cool to touch. Whipped butter and vanilla first; then whipped in cream cheese 4oz at a time, just enough to mix. Do not over mix! Added confectioners sugar 2/3 cup at a time. Again did not over mix. Mixture gets thinner with more sugar and over mixing, NOT thicker. My frosting was thick and even had to use quite a bit of force for piping. It does get softer but that was the result of handling of piping bag. Simply popped in fridge for a bit, and ready to star again. Loved that it was not overly sweet!
Review:

5

text:
I made this and it turned out phenomenal.  I make it exactly like the recipe stated, creaming the butter and cream cheese together first, adding the vanilla and mixing it in.  Then, gradually adding the powdered sugar. Then it tasted spectacular just as it was.  After tasting it I decided it was delicious but I wanted some lemon flavor so I added a few squeezes of lemon.  This is an easy, tangy, not too sweet frosting.  My kitchen was very warm, so let the frosting cool down in the refrigerator to thicken up before I spread it on.

userID:
497710
Display Name:
Angela Gregory
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5958057.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I did not make any significant changes to the makeup of the recipe. 
I did follow the instructions of another user that recommended to blend the butter fully with the powdered sugar prior to adding the cold cream cheese. I have made this recipe in the past and it was quite runny (though delicious), this time I did as was recommended and it turned out perfectly. I was able to frost my cake immediately. One reason I thought this might be the case is that cream cheese typically has a stabilizer in it, and high-shear mixing (like what you're doing in a food processorg) can break down stabilizers and make whatever you're making very runny. But that technique was perfect!!
Review:

5

text:
I found Sam’s Famous Carrot Cake which I made a few changes while putting it together.  I left my review for the cake.  Someone who also baked that cake recommended this icing.  I made a few changes because my hubby loves double, sweet icing.  I doubled everything except the butter and cream cheese to make it sweeter for him.  Putting these two together with the changes for the sweet, double icing produced an amazing cake!  We had to try it immediately after it cooled.  Can’t wait to try it tomorrow as some folks say it’s even better after a day in the fridge!  Thanks so much for sharing this recipe!  Yummy!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Cream cheese frosting is one of those things that everyone likes a certain way. I like enough sweet so that it doesn’t taste like pure cheese cake. Given my preferences, I used this version of this frosting: 16 oz of cream cheese, 1 cup of sifted powered sugar, 1/3 cup softened butter, and split the vanilla extract in half to add a half teaspoon of almond extract. It was fluffy, not runny at all, with a little tang, but not so much that it clenched your jaw! Great, soft consistency and balanced flavor.

userID:
3269007
Display Name:
Flamingo Cat

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great pointers for this recipe and to flavor it! First blend the cream cheese by itself until creamy. Next add your flavoring/extract.  (I made lemon flavored and ended up using almost half a jar of the extract.). You will want to make the flavor a little bit stronger than what you want. It will tame down when you add the other ingredients. Next mix in your vanilla. Then mix in the butter. You will need to sift the sugar before you measure it. If you don’t you’re going to be putting in more sugar and it will be lumpy.  Pour in the sugar half cup at a time, mix thoroughly and keep adding sugar until it gets to the sweetness you desire. If for some reason it starts to get runny you can use powdered buttermilk to help thicken it back up.  If you blend the cream cheese by it self first you shouldn’t have that issue.  I did not cut the recipe, but I did add a smidge more vanilla. I made a layered 9 x 13 cake - there was plenty of frosting to cover it.

This frosting is very good. I made half the recipe and it came out perfect. Follow the suggestion of using the butter and cream cheese at room temperature. Your results will definitely depend on it. city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Fantastic! It's true: this recipe is not too sweet, and if you really want the taste of cream cheese rather than sugar to come out in the frosting, this recipe will work for you. I halved it for a smaller carrot cake and used whipped cream cheese rather than regular, and I used a splash more vanilla since I like the flavor. It was perfect. Since I mixed by hand, I had to really take time and whip the ingredients to get rid of the  sugar lumps, but the results were awesome. On my second go around, I might try adding orange zest to the recipe for a change up. I highly recommend this recipe. It came out like a frosting, not an icing, in my opinion. If you want a sweeter, less piquant cream cheese frosting, look elsewhere.

userID:
22615628
Display Name:
edenhensley
isPro:
