photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674146.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading reviews that said this recipe could be a little runny, we skipped softening the butter and cream cheese substitute and started with them at room temperature instead.

We first sifted the 2 cups of powdered sugar and then slowly blended the other ingredients into it using a hand mixer set on low, first the vanilla, then the butter (we used sheep butter at room temperature, not softened).

We substituted 8 ounces of Tofuti Better Than Cream Cheese for the Cream Cheese. After we added  one package of Tofuti, again at room temperature not softened, and had a nice consistency, we tasted the frosting. Tofuti has a different taste than cream cheese and can be overpowering. We liked the consistency and the taste so we skipped adding more Tofuti (we would have added the second package in batches to avoid getting too solid in structure).

We'll definitely make again.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2017-10-22T19:07:17.007
helpfulCount:
0

Been making this recipe for years. I make it just as the recipe says. It is a little thin after you add all the sugar. The trick is to let it stiffen up in the fridge. I usually make mine a day ahead of time and it comes out great. I uses it on its own or under fondant. And keep the cake in the fridge until close to serving time. The flavor is always a big hit!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7097371.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Amazing frosting - Do NOT let your butter & cream cheese soften too much or frosting becomes runny.   I chopped up cold butter and cream cheese, this allowed me to beat them furiously with the mixture and and the frosting did not become runny.   Also, if you sift the powdered sugar it blends much more easily with the frosting, thus you don't have to mix it quite as much so the frosting does't get hot from the friction of the mixer.   I did not have to add more than 2 cups sifted powdered sugar and the frosting was perfect.

For a nice twist, try adding the zest of one lemon (Meyer), it made the frosting even better on my carrot cake....LOVE this recipe!

I made this for a carrot cake recipe on here (Allrecipes app). It is fantastic!! I followed the ingredients to the letter. I did take the advice of one reviewer and blended the cream cheese and vanilla and simply cut in the butter. This always works better for my sugar cookies too. I had two cups of sifted powder sugar and that's all I had in my home. I was a bit worried as other viewers said they used three cups to get a sweeter taste. For me the ingredients in this recipe is perfect. It has a cheesecake like taste and has just enough sweet to cheese ratio. My husband loves the real cream cheese frosting so I know he will love this!! This will stay in my favorites!! :)

I made this for my dad, who doesn't care for "too sweet". This was perfect! The cream cheese really came through, but it was still sweet enough for a cake. The only thing I had a problem with is that it is very thick. Display Name:
Toni Hovis

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3828513.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The consistency and creaminess is superb. The only reason I gave it 4 stars instead of 5 is because it was not quite sweet enough for my carrot cake. It tasted more to the sweetness of cheese cake than icing. I added confectioners sugar to taste; approx. 3.5 - 4 cups overall.  I also want to add that I used unsalted butter, so that was not the issue with sweetness.
**One helpful tip to anyone making icing for the 1st time, DO NOT melt your butter. This is why icing comes out runny. Let your butter and cream cheese get to room temperature, cream the two together, then mix in the confectioners sugar, then vanilla.

text:
Just made this tonight...sweetie raved and raved.  I left out raisins, added a t. Vanilla, a t. Almond, about a t. Lemon peel (dried), 1 teaspoon each of allspice, cinnamon, and nutmeg.  I used 3 c shredded carrots and I chopped walnuts and added at the end of mixing.  My flours were 1 c. Spelt flour and 1 c. Almond flour and added the rest of what the recipe called for.  I put it in an oblong pampered chef casserole (13 X ?) and cooked about 50 minutes.  Perfect.  I topped it, when a bit cooler with Cream Cheese 11 icing on this site.  I only made half the frosting recipe as that was exactly perfect for the cake shape used.  Next time I'm using applesauce in place of the oil.  I've done that with a few other dishes in the past and it was absolutely great!  Do this, people...OMG.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This has awesome cream cheese flavor, but in order to give this true frosting consistency you will need to slightly alter it, so I can only give 3 stars as written.  I add an additional cup (or even a little more, depending on the humidity) of sifted confectioners sugar. I find the frosting has a much better consistency and it is the ideal sweetness without being nauseatingly sweet like many frostings are.  Additionally, I like to add 1/8-1/4 tsp of salt as I think it heightens the flavor of the cream cheese and provides necessary balance, especially if you're serving this on chocolate cake.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-04-28T20:49:04.94

text:
Perfect! Not sugary-sweet like some recipes. This recipe is a smooth, cream cheesey, perfectly sweetened delight. I always use salted butter (melted in the microwave), then whip everything in my KitchenAid until fluffy. Put the frosting in the fridge for a couple hours so it gets a little firmer before using it. This recipe cut in half frosts the top of a 9x13 cake nicely.

text:
Very simple to make and just right for my carrot cake! It was plenty sweet. Was able to get it going with a fork and a bit of turning while watching tv. As the picture shows, it wasn't too frosty looking, but my ugly cake was good. 

I changed the ratios to:
5/8 cup Cream Cheese
3 Tbsp. Butter
1 Cup Confectioners Sugar
1 tsp vanilla extract.
This was enough to fully cover  the top and sides of the cake baked in a 9" Bundt pan

text:
This is a great base recipe for Cream Cheese Frosting. However, Diabetes runs in my family so I am used to having a lot less sugar in my food and I prefer my frosting a lot less sweet than this recipe turned out. So, I substituted all the powdered sugar for 1 cup of granulated sugar and 1 1/4 cup light brown sugar. OMG it is scrumptious! Also, any left over frosting is positively glorious with sliced fruits especially apples!

text:
I have made this icing several times , once with the butter, the other times with out.  Its as good with out the butter as it is with.
 I prepared the cake the day before and refrigerate it overnight .  Letting the cake sit over night  gives the cream cheese time  absorb all of the flavors. My family loves it. I use the recipe as a guide line, especially the powder sugar.  Depending on your sweet tooth  or lack of sweet tooth, it very easy to regulate.
I'm going to try the chocolate next.

text:
This was great! Used it to top a rhubarb cake I made. I followed this recipe exactly as directed and in my opinion, it was neither too sweet nor too cheesy. The only issue: we had it in the fridge for a while (less than an hour) to cool while the cake was baking and it got a little too thick. This was also true once the frosting was on the cake -- it formed a thick layer that sometimes peeled off the cake. The flavor was perfect cream cheese frosting. Just could have stood to have a little extra liquid/creaminess and adhere better to the cake, hence 4 stars instead of 5.

STUPID GOOD!  I just made this wonderful cream cheese frosting to pipe onto my pumpkin cupcakes for an early thanksgiving gathering. If you make this "as is" I can tell you that it all its supposed to be, Cream cheese frosting!!!  That's it. I wish more people would just make and rate recipes and not change it. If you change it, post your own variation with your own title. As for this little gem. It's perfect!

I was one that changed this recipe some. It's a great place to start. I did 3 cups of sugar, 1.5 tsp vanilla, and the zest of a lemon but it was pretty lemony. It was delicious on carrot cake. I'd do the zest of 1/2 a lemon if I didn't want the lemon to stand out too much but still wanted to add some freshness. Without alterations it is still yummy, just tastes like cheesecake.

I use this recipe everything I make this icing. I will say my family prefers it to be a little sweeter so I add an extra cup of powdered sugar. As for people saying it too runny, I have never had this problem. I always use Philadelphia Cream cheese and after I get it all creamed together it goes in the refrigerator for a bit and by the time I ready to  frost my cakes it's a perfect consistency. Don't believe any of the negative reviews because it really is a yummy icing.

userID:
647546
Display Name:
Bleu Belle
isPro:

followersCount:

followingCount:

madeRecipesCount:
37
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Not an icing yet more dense and flavorful than a (buttercream) frosting. The secret to getting it light is whip the (softened) cream cheese until light and fluffy, then add (softened, not melted) butter and whip again until light and fluffy. Add the powdered sugar 1/2 C. at a time and blend thoroughly after each addition to keep it light. I use the same formula as pabbydog which is about half the recipe to cover an 8x12 cake: 8 oz cream cheese, 1/4 C. butter and 2C. sifted powdered sugar, with half the vanilla extract. Was superb on a strawberry cake; looking to make a creamsicle cake with this next!

text:
This recipe was great! After reading the other reviews, I modified the recipe a bit by lessening the amount of cream cheese and butter, and increasing the amount of vanilla. I also added a bit of strawberry puree to it that gave it a really great strawberry flavor (but made it runny). Overall, this recipe is great! Will definitely be making again.

Fantastic recipe. Super easy with ingredients typically on hand. Used it to cover a lemon cake I made for Easter and it was absolutely delicious. I wouldn't change a thing. I read a few reviews that said this recipe was runny, but I didn't have that experience at all. When I took my whisk out of the bowl, nothing fell off. I would consider this a reasonably stiff recipe, but definitely easy enough to spread. Absolutely perfect.

This is fabulous & easy. Cut down cream cheese to 8ozs & butter to 1/4 cup. Used 2 cups sifted powder sugar & 2 teaspoons good vanilla. Thanks for this great recipe.

Display Name:

isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe, in contrast to others, gives you the tangy cream cheese taste, as opposed to the overly-sweet taste of other some other frosting. Since I was making a double recipe of cupcakes, I decided that, before I doubled the amount of frosting, I should try it first after making the regular amount. Though I enjoyed it, I found it just a bit too tangy, so I added just one more cream cheese package with the rest of the ingredients (making it 3/4 of the amount of cream cheese which the recipe calls for). This change made it almost perfect; it had  a much better balance between tangy and sweet, and it was fantastic on my cupcakes. Because I made this modification, I'm only giving the recipe four stars.

This is really a good recipe. I've been using this for at least 23yrs. To keep it from being runny, beat the cream cheese straight out the fridge. Let the butter sit out slightly before you blend with cream cheese. Using 1-1/2 bars of cream cheese will give you more of that cream cheese taste that u're looking for and won't be as sweet

text:
Great recipe! After reading the ingredients, I doubled the recipe since it was for a 9"x9" 2 -layer cake and it worked well. The only change I made was to make my own powdered sugar from raw unrefined sugar in a food processor. If not for my poor frosting skills, I'm sure it would have looked nicer. A bonus was that I did have some left over frosting to use for graham cracker spread or for a small batch of cupcakes :). This was the perfect, NOT too sweet cream cheesy frosting recipe I was looking for. Thank you for sharing!

Just tested this for an upcoming party, where I plan to use it on carrot cake, so I only made half a batch this time. My step-son took one taste, his eyes widened, and the words 'Oh..My..God' slowly came out of his mouth. I knew at  this point that the test was a success, so I took the plan a step further and piped the frosting into cut strawberries (am also testing the pipe-ability and it seems fine as long as it doesn't get too warm while mixing), and that was an even bigger hit! It was super easy but looks and tastes extremely extravagant :)

text:
I have been making this recipe for years from this page and I just have to say: USE MEXICAN VANILLA it is SO MUCH BETTER that it's ridiculous. 
I have a huge bottle of aged Mexican Vanilla that was given to me by my great grandmother years ago. I never had any idea how amazing it was until we moved again this year and my Vanilla accidentally got packed into a box and stuck in storage. I made this frosting with my sister's ordinary vanilla extract and the result is tasty but the flavor was missing something and I realized it's the deliciousness of my amazing Mexican Vanilla. It just plain tastes better.

I followed this recipe exactly the way it says.  It was way too clumpy so I decided to put a 4 tablespoons of butter and the cream cheese in a microwavable bowl along with the sugar on top and put it in the microwave for 15 seconds which makes it easier to mix and creamer.

country:
None
text:
I put 1 1/2 teaspoons Vanilla extract in due to my taste buds not liking the first batch I made.  I also made sure that my butter and cream cheese were incredibly soft before creaming them together.  One thing that is important is to add the confectioners sugar in increments, not all at once.  I then mixed it on level 6 on my kitchen aid mixer until impeccably smooth and light.  I used it on my pumpkin bars.  This time it turned out better than those expensive little bakery cupcakes you pay $4 a piece for!

userID:
794663
Display Name:
UNCLEBEN1980
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This served as a great starting point, but like other reviewers I found the proportions to be off; namely, the recipe does not include enough confectioner's sugar. For me it had nothing to do with sweetness or flavor (I happen to like a cream cheese frosting that really does taste like cream cheese), but with consistency. The frosting this recipe yielded was far too soft and thin to put on the cake for which I made it-- it would have all dripped right off in a matter of minutes. Luckily, it was the week of Christmas, and I was doing lots of cooking/baking, so I just happened to have an additional bag of confectioner's sugar on hand; and it took almost the entire bag to get the frosting to a consistency that would not drip like goo off the cake. Having said that, once the consistency was corrected, the taste was perfect. I'll temper all this by also saying that it was pretty rainy the whole week leading up to Christmas, so perhaps the air was more humid than normal and that accounts for some of the problem?  At any rate, I'd suggest giving this recipe a try, but be prepared that you might need to add extra confectioner's sugar. Fortunately, the sugar isn't expensive, so buying an extra bag isn't cost-prohibitive. Also be prepared that if you must add as much sugar as did I, you will end up with almost twice the frosting you probably need! You'll have to find reasons to smear cream cheese frosting on different foods for days (not the worst problem in the world :-)  ).
Review:

userID:
2835236
Display Name:
purple_inferno
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/929219.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe. Rich, tangy, sweet... Mmmm. I love cream cheese icing, and this one is great.

For Piping READ THIS!

Use all room temperature ingredients and make as directed, but add and extra cup of confectioners sugar. Yes, it does make it sweeter, but it is the only way this will stand up to piping. Depending on climate, humidity, and many other factors, you may need more/less sugar. Once it's whipped, the icing should hold a medium-firm peak. Use Philadelphia cream cheese, and do not use light... full fat regular is the only way to go. Pipe it chilled ( I chilled mine for a few hours). It will still be softer than, say, a buttercream, but your piping will hold.

Once I piped this on cupcakes and let them sit for a few hours in a pretty warm house full of people, it held.

You could go ahead and use it as written and pipe it cold, but it may fall as it warms up... what's the point in going to the effort of piping gorgeous swirls only to have them fall? Before I added the extra sugar, it was a bit soft for piping, IMO.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious!! I have made just as written and with a tweak or two and I've never been disappointed! For those who are finding it too runny, two things come to mind. First, you must use either real butter OR the baking margarine. Light margarine and whipped margarine will NOT work in this recipe. Also, make sure it is softened from sitting at room temperature, not from being softened in the microwave -- this changes the consistency and will cause your frosting to become thin instead of thick and creamy. Hope this helps some future bakers some!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2012-10-27T13:10:26.51
helpfulCount:

text:
I did not care for this recipe. If you only use the small amount of sugar called for you have basically a butter cream cheese spread.  it is not sweet. It doesn't even taste like icing. In order to make this recipe work, you need to add at least another cup of sugar. I used 2 cups more of sugar. I also added a pinch of salt. Prior to adding the salt, it still had a bland flavor, even though I used very good (Madagascar)  vanilla and all that sugar.

text:
I had 24 carrot cupcakes to top and about 1 1/2 bricks of cream cheese, so I used about 3/4 stick of butter, 1 tsp. vanilla, 1/2+ tsp. lemon juice, and a little more than 2 cups of the p-sugar. It is scrumptious, but after a generous topping on the little cakes I still had almost a cup left over. Tip: to best save for future use, chill and press film-wrap on top to remove any little air pockets before sealing container(works great on a lot of things!). Now all I have to do is figure out what to use the leftovers on!

text:
Amazingly creamy-cheesy flavor.  Beautifully spreadable.  Left out about 2 Tbsp. of the sugar, and it spread onto a three layer cake perfectly well.  Not like decorator icing, but like a nice icing all the same.  Best of all, I used non-fat cream cheese - so I'm not eating gobs of fat, just a lot of butter, but not a lot of butter and cream cheese fat too, *&* I don't feel like I'm eating pure sugar.  Goes so well with Sam's wonderful carrot cake from this site.  Thanks so much for helping me find an icing I actually enjoy.  (yep, I usually just use a touch of powdered sugar, which is usually fine, but sometimes a cook does want that iced finish.... now I've got a great recipe for an icing in my repertoire)

text:
This is fabulous frosting.  I only need a little more than a cup of frosting (1 9x13 carrot cake and my family likes less rather than more frosting.)  After cutting the recipe in 1/2 I added 1/2 extra sugar to help it be a little thicker.  I also was using cold cream cheese (1/3 fat) and butter so I put it in a glass bowl and put it on top of a bowl full of hot water (double boiler style, just no on my stove) that made it easier to combine the ingredients.

text:
I love making this recipe! Once you mak your own frosting you will never want to buy it from the store. AMAZING On red velvet and carrot cake... I used Duncan Hine's red velvet cake mix and filled mini cupcakes. Put them into the oven and then let them cool completely. I take a pastry bag and fill it with frostng. Then I push the icing into the cupcake and (using the point like a star on the pastry bag) I keep a little amount of frosting on the top. They are easy to make and I always bring them to parties. They are a real hit!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was looking for a basic Cream Cheese frosting and came across this recipe. I altered it slightly because I needed to double the recipe and didn't have enough cream cheese on hand. I replaced half of the cream cheese with Mascarpone ( a slightly sweeter and lighter cream cheese). I also added a couple of teaspoons of Marsala wine and and an additional 1/2 cup of confectioners sugar. Finally I added some cinnamon (to your desired tasted).  This resulted in an extremely light and airy texture, without taking away from that beautiful cream cheese taste. My family and friends love the recipe so much, this has become my new go to recipe!

text:
Very good frosting!!! Taste is great. I halved the recipe and used more sugar. Used 8 ounces of cream cheese, 3 1/2 cups of confectioners sugar, 1/3 cup butter, and 1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract. Found that it wasn't very fluffy but very creamy and smooth. I was expecting a fluffy icing, so that's the reason for only 4 stars. However, the taste was wonderful. There was enough (with the measurements above) to not overly frost about 20 devil's food cupcakes.

I like this cream cheese frosting. It has a smooth consistency and tasted great on "Sam's Famous Carrot Cake" from allrecipes. I doubled the vanilla. I recommend starting with all ingredients at room temperature to ensure easy mixing. Some reviewers thought it needed more sugar, but I liked it just the way it is. I would recommend trying it as written first, then add more sugar if it isn't to your taste.

text:
This is my go-to frosting for every cake I make. People RAVE about my cakes, and I attribute this to the awesome recipes in my arsenal: Easy Eggless Chocolate Cake, topped with this cream cheese frosting (sometimes with Sweetened Whipped Cream between cake layers).   I must note, however, that I prefer a cake frosting to be not as sweet as a regular butter frosting. My husband, on the other hand, would actually like it if I made the frosting sweeter. So bear that in mind, depending on your sweet tooth.

text:
I'm a newbie to cooking and baking so I wanted something easy after my attempt at Italian Buttercream failed miserably.  This recipe is simple and GOOD!  I let the cream cheese and sliced-up butter sit on the counter for about 1 hour only.  Then I partially creamed them using a hand-mixer.  I ended up halving the amount of sugar b/c I didn't want it too sweet.  Once all the ingredients were added, then I really whipped the frosting.  It came out tasting like cheese cake and w/ great texture (not runny) so I'm a happy camper!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my first allrecipes review. What an awesome frosting! Unbelievably simple and quick to make, and when mixed with a handmixer the texture is wonderfully whipped and fluffy. What I really like about it is that you could very easily tweak it to your taste without a whole lot of modification. If you make it as is and decide you want it a little bit sweeter, just add in more sugar. If it's too cheesey, add in some butter. Personally, I found it perfect exactly as is...I didn't find it too cheesey at all as other reviewers had mentioned. I made half the batch of this frosting for a whole batch of cinnamon buns and it was plenty. What an easy way to up the wow factor on your desserts...quick and easy luxury!

I was surprised by the actual flavor of this. It basically taste like a "very lightly sweetened" whipped cream cheese, not like a frosting or icing! I made 1/4 of the recipe, because I was planning on using this to ice some cinnamon rolls. But, it was too strong tasting for that, and I ran out of powdered sugar to adjust it. userID:
5346723
Display Name:
pinkbarbie23
isPro:

0

1
favoritesCount:
1

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the recipe exactly and it was too thin and not very sweet so I added 3 more cups of powdered sugar at 1/2 cup intervals beating in to taste after each addition.  I was looking for a more thick and sweet cream cheese frosting, however this recipe is between an icing and a frosting in consistency.  I agree with others that this would be a great icing on cinnamon rolls or even on a simple cake but not for stiff piping peaks.  I refrigerated it overnight to give it a little more thickness but when you let it get to room temperature it loses it's shape again and I hate cold frosting/icing on my cupcakes.  I wanted to up the flavor a little more to give it some kind of a boost so I added 1/2 a vanilla bean to the icing.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2010-09-08T19:54:48.563
helpfulCount:

text:
I made Carrot Cake III and, based on recommendations from various cake recipe reviews, I chose this one because people said it was more cheesy and less sweet.  Boy, I wish I'd read all the reviews of this frosting first before I made it.  Mine turned out like soup.  It would be fine for glazing a cake, but not frosting it.  It would just run down the sides, as others have noted.  I added double the powdered sugar called for, and it's still too runny.  If it were just for a regular meal, I'd let it go, but this is for my daughter's birthday today, so I want it to be really nice.  I give it one star only because it tastes good.

country:
None
text:
this was exactly the recipe I was looking for. My sister wanted a strawberry cake with cream cheese icing for her baby shower, and after looking at the pictures, and reading the reviews I choose this one. I give it 5 stars for the taste, as it was really good, but only 3 because of the consistency. I know cream cheese frosting isn't very thick to begin with, but trying to ice the cake-a 'baby-belly', made with the Wilton soccer ball pan- was really difficult and messy. I ended up having to cover the cake in fondant, even though my sister didn't want that, because the icing alone just didn't look good. I followed the recipe all the way, but it was just to thin, even after adding about a cup more confectioner's sugar.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I can't believe I haven't rated this until now.  This is practically the ONLY frosting recipe I use anymore.  I refuse to use canned frostings... the so-called "Cream cheese" frosting in a can taste like chemicals!  This recipe is an absolute WINNER.  I make it exactly as stated, only I cut it in half for the perfect amount for a 13x9x2 cake.  I'd keep it as is if you are making a layered cake.  As others have noted, this is for real cream cheese lovers.  It's not sickly sweet, but very cheesy and delicious.  I've made it for carrot cake, chocolate cake, and most recently, David's Yellow Cake, which can be found on this site.  If you love cream cheese, you will NOT be disappointed!

Update 052214...Just made it again. As noted above I made it a little sweeter for my family by adding 1/4 cup of white sugar. Toasted chopped pecans with a little butter. I also added 1 tsp of lemon flavor. Refrigerated over night. Very pleased with this recipe. The four stars are for the original recipe. I don't take away from a recipe when I make the decision to edit it for my personal taste, because then it is a new recipe.

I tasted the frosting after I blended the first three ingredients together and thought it was perfect. Then I added the vanilla and ick didn't like it! I didn't put more than the recipe called for and am surprised so many reviewers liked more. For me it gave it an overwhelming vanilla taste that killed the cream cheese flavor. Definitely will make again less the vanilla.

text:
With the proper adjustments, this recipe is outstanding.  Double the amount of vanilla extract and/or add vanilla bean seeds from one vanilla bean + increase the confectioners' sugar to 2 1/2 cups.  I had leftovers after frosting a 2 layer 9-inch round red velvet cake.  The frosting itself tastes like cheesecake, which is awesome.  The only thing I hate about it is that I have to refrigerate any cupcakes or cakes that I use this frosting with.  Cakes tend to dry out in the refrigerator.  However, that does not matter when the taste, quality, and quantity of this frosting are unbelievably sensational.

text:
I used this icing on Carrot cake from this site.  http://allrecipes.com/Recipe/Sams-Famous-Carrot-Cake/Detail.aspx  I used a tsp more pure vanilla, 1/2 the sugar,but added 1/2 cup of clover honey and juice from one small orange, and a 1/4 cup of butter milk, and a 1/4 cup heavy whipping cream.  This is a great, easy frosting that tastes incredible.  This turned out to be the best carrot cake I have ever tasted!

userID:
2539801
Display Name:
Jim Wiesen
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
8
favoritesCount:
46
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6137462.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used this icing with the Pumpkin Gingerbread recipe (on this site) and it was the perfect match!  I did make a couple changes.  First, I halved the recipe.  Next, I added an extra Tbs of vanilla (as others have suggested).  This first attempt turned out very cream cheesy (but good).  The next time I made it, I halved everything EXCEPT for the confectioners sugar (used 2 Cups).  This time, it was the perfect blend of cream cheese to sweetness.  Also, if you're looking for the great taste, but are trying to save a few calories, you can safely use 1/3 fat Philly Cream Cheese with absolutely NO impact on the final product.  My family thought it was the full fat fare.  :-)  Finally, halving the recipe with the extra cup of conf sugar yielded enough frosting to cover two 9x5 pumpkin loaves.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2009-10-17T07:08:25.003

text:
This will be the recipe I use from now on!  I didn't read the reviews first, but I too only used 1 8 oz. cream cheese, 1/4 c. butter, 2 c. powdered sugar and 1 tsp. vanilla.  I was glad it turned out wonderfully and was the perfect consistancy and amount for the top of my 9 x 13 cake.  You'll need to make a double batch if you plan to frost sides or layers.  Easy to remember rule of thumb: 2c sugar to every 8 oz. pkg crm.chs.  Otherwise recipes use too much sugar or too much cheese.  Yummy!

text:
This is an excellent frosting and I didn't find it to have that 'cream cheesy' taste that everyone keeps mentioning.  It does make A LOT of frosting, so cut the recipe in half if you are frosting a 9x13 or 24 cupcakes.  I whipped the cream cheese, added the vanilla and then added the butter slowly.  I added the sugar until it tasted good to me, so I have no idea how much I put in.  The frosting was light and fluffy and had a nice light taste to it....not overbearing at all.  I frosted my red velvet cupcakes with it and they were dreamy!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A little too rich of a cream cheese taste for my liking.  I took the advice of some of the reviews and started off with only 8 oz. cream cheese and a little extra powdered sugar.  However, when I taste tested it, I thought it was too sweet, so I slowly added more cream cheese, tasting it all the way.  Eventually I had added the whole second 8 oz package of cream cheese and thought it tasted just right.  But, when I tasted it with the red velvet cake I frosted with it, it was too rich and I wished that I had never added the second cream cheese.  So, be careful when you are taste testing and keep in mind what you will be eating this frosting with.

This was my first attempt making cream cheese frosting, and I was so happy with this recipe. I made exactly 1/4 of the recipe, and did not change anything. This frosting is much better than the ready to use ones; those are not even comparable to this. It is more like the frosting in a specialty bakery shop. It is not sweet at all, and it the taste reminds me of a good cheesecake but much lighter. Thank you for sharing this recipe.

text:
The original recipe was good, but too "creamcheesey" for my tastes (I know some people who aren't in to sweet frosting that would love it though). I only gave it 4 stars because of this. I made some modifications, including adding another teaspoon of vanilla and another cup of sifted sugar, and would give it 5 stars with the modifications. I also refridgerated the frosting for 30+ minutes then pulled it out and re-whipped it because it was so hot in my house... Great recipe!

text:
Absolutely a 5-star recipe!  This was delicious.  I used it to frost my daughter's birthday cake and I divided it in half and made half of it chocolate cream cheese frosting by adding some cocoa powder, to taste (and added some brown coloring).  Both the regular and chocolate were excellent and everyone loved them both!  Definitely my new go-to cream cheese frosting now!  It spread great too...best after having sat in the fridge for a short amount of time (not too long though or it'll be too thick to spread). EDIT: Made a chocolate version of this for the second time and gotta say, we didn't really care for it this time around.  I think I'll definitely stick to the original plain cream cheese with this.  Plus, the color is a very light brown, which isn't what I usually want when we want chocolate frosting.

text:
This frosting was amazing!!! I was a little worried about it not being sweet enough. I liked it, but I was making it for someone else and I wasnt sure if they would. The reviews I read said they put 2 extra cups of sugar but I did not want to make it super sweet so I put 1 extra cup. I then used it with the Strawberry cake from Scratch recipe and everyone loved it! I have had soo many people ask me for the recipes. They all thought that the sweetness of the frosting was perfect, not too sweet but not unsweet either.

this frosting is perfect.  make sure you soften up the butter & cream cheese before you start and don't go crazy with the vanilla.  can be colored very easily, just add a couple drops of food coloring while you're mixing it.  it's great on chocolate cake, carrot cake, as a fruit dip, with a spoon, on fingers..

None
text:
This is a great recipe. But we have an even easier one, We simply buy a tub of cream cheese frosting and add an 8oz package of softened cream cheese to it. set it in the fridge for about 15 minutes to stiffen a little since beating it thins it. Then you are ready to go. Not too sweet and not to twangy, the kids love it.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So easy and versatile! I added a little red food colouring to make pink icing for the cupcakes I served at our local church play group for Valentines Day. It was the perfect consistency to pipe on with my cake decorating kit (not too thick) to create a rosette effect. A couple of things though; If you've refrigerated it ahead of time you'll want to let it stand out of the fridge for about 10 minutes so it will be soft enough to work with. In the same token once made you wont want to leave them out too long, since the icing does contain cream cheese and will start to go funny after about 30 minutes depending on the temp of the room they're sitting in of coarse!

text:
The first time I made this I followed the recipe exactly, it was good but a bit too sweet on top of devil's food cupcakes. The second time I made this I added 1 tsp vanilla extract and an additional 1/4 cup butter. After everything was mixed I turned up the mixer on high and whipped it for about 2 minutes until the frosting was light and fluffy without the use of whipped cream. Definitely a keeper!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a pretty good cream cheese frosting and spreads nicely onto a cake without too much hassle. I did add an additional cup of confectioner's sugar to make it a bit sweeter as I wanted it a bit sweeter for the cake I made, but I also tasted it before adding the additional cup and it's still quite good without additional sugar. It has a nice not very sugary-sweet cream cheese flavor without the additional cup, and even one more cup still didn't make it overly sweet, so I would recommend it either way. That's the beauty of frosting - taste it and add more sugar if it's not enough for you!
Review:

i realized that I only had one package of cream cheese, so I ended up making a buttercream-cream cheese frosting. I followed all the ingredients, only using one package cream cheese, and 2 teaspoons vanilla and another 3/4 cup of powdered sugar. It turned of fantastic, and the taste of cream cheese was still there and very good. 
I know I made alterations to the recipe, and usually am against those who review negatively after they have changed the recipe entirely. I am therefore giving this a 5-star rating as I am sure it would have been just as delicious and easy if i would not have made these small changes.

text:
This is a great recipe. The icing isn't too sweet and really has that cream cheese taste.  The only downside I've found is that the icing is somewhat too runny to ice a two layer cake.  It drips down the side and doesn't stay in place.  I try to refrigerate the icing for at least 2 hours before icing a cake, to avoid this problem.

text:
This is truly a wonderful cream cheese frosting. It's simple and creamy with a real cream cheese taste. I have made it twice, once with regular and once with reduced fat cream cheese. The reduced fat changes the consistency only slightly, but not enough to make a big difference unless you're tasting it straight out of the bowl. Food coloring is a fun addition, too!

text:
I made this frosting today to ice a 2-layer strawberry cake. It turned out a little more firm than I would like, especially to ice a layer cake with. At the end I popped the last bit in the microwave for about 5 seconds so that I could make the top of the cake smooth. I also added a 3rd cup of confectioners sugar and I thought it made the icing a little too sweet, especially for strawberry cake. If I were to make this again I'd probably add a teaspoon of lemon juice and stick to the 2 cups of sugar.

text:
I loved this recipe.  I enjoy the cheesecake taste more than a sweet taste.  I however changed a few things.

Instead of Vanilla extract I used Almond extract.
1/4 cup Amaretto Liqueur (I used Disaronno, if you have it, its great)
1/4 cup Orange juice, or Lemon juice.  Lemon curd might be good as well.

I used this on a Carrot cake, but I am sure it would be great on other things as well.

text:
The taste was good, and that's why it gets 3 stars. But the texture was just awful! It was so runny that no amount of powdered sugar (literally all the sugar I had in the cupboard) or refrigerating (about 5 hours) was enough to fix it. It is realistically more of a glaze than a frosting, and not at all what I wanted. If you're looking for a fluffy frosting, this is definitely not it.

I used slightly less butter (3/4 stick) because I prefer less oily food. This is the best icing I've ever made. And it covered a bundt cake with plenty to spare.
3/19 I added an extra cup of powdered sugar to thicken it up, decrease the oiliness, and it made more than plenty for a 1/2 sheet cake with some to spare!

country:
None
text:
Lovely! I used Victoria Island cream cheese (which is by far my favorite cream cheese; tastes less processed than Philadelphia cream cheese, in my opinion), but found it a bit too thick to spread, so I added a bit more vanilla (probably doubled it) and the consistency/taste was good. My cake still crumbled a bit while I was spreading, but once they taste it, who's going to look at it? I filled and topped a double layer chocolate cake (Dark Chocolate Cake, from this site), and added half a can of cherry pie filling on top. Looks fantastic! Tastes good, too. :P This recipe was enough to do one double layered 9" cake and one double layered 6" cake, not being very generous on the icing (I figured I ought to cut down a little with the cherry topping! Didn't want to overdo it). Thanks for the recipe!

text:
This was the easiest frosting recipe I have ever made!!  Both my husband and children ask for the fluffy white icing anytime I am going to make a cake or pumpkin roll.  The key to the recipe is making sure that the cream cheese is softened along with the butter, otherwise it will be lumpy.  They always ask to have some leftover, just to lick off of their fingers....

text:
This was a pretty good frosting. I used it on "The Best Carrot Cake Ever" and it turned out well. I live in the Czech Republic and don't have access to cream cheese, so I bought "tvaroh" and it was so similiar that it tasted pretty much the same. Make sure that the butter is very soft before you mix! My frosting had a few small bits of solid butter, which made the icing layer at the top look a little flawed.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was delicious, my husband raved about it. To make it interesting, I added about 3-4 tbsp of Bailey's Irish creme liquer. (This is especially nice for a St. Patrick's day cake). 
The only thing that slightly disappointed me is that it was very soft, and it made it pretty difficult to ice the cake. I had intended to pipe a border on the cake for a little decoration, but it was way too soft to pipe.  My cake was completely cooled, so it wasn't the cake, but the house WAS warm. I put the icing into the freezer for about 20 minutes and it still didn't make a difference. Anyway, once I got it on the cake and into the frig, it hardened up.  But don't try to pipe this stuff, it seems to melt way too fast when exposed to any kind of warmth.

text:
I don't even like cream cheese frosting, but I was in charge of making carrot cake for an anniversary party.  I decided to make this recipe, and I had to taste it.  I surprised myself, it's excellent.  I added at least a cup more of the sugar so it wasn't quite so tart.  I had no issues with the frosting being runny, but I didn't let the cream cheese/butter sit too long.  It probably wasn't quite room temp yet.  I used my KitchenAid mixer and the consistency is just right.

I made it for the "Best Carrot Cake Ever" recipe on this site and I'm not a huge fan of carrot cake OR cream cheese frosting (my husband and coworkers are), but even I liked the cake - with the frosting being my favorite part. I did add about a quarter cup more powdered sugar to take some of the bite out of it, but the texture was fine even before I did that. Definately not a runny frosting, though I wish I had a 220v compliant mixer to have fluffed it up more than I managed to by hand. One of the hazards of moving overseas, I guess.

text:
This recipe produces a frosting which indeed has a lovely cream cheese flavor - not overly sweet, which complemented the brownie recipe I used it on very well.  however, I am only giving it three stars because of the texture - it is way too thin for my taste - more like a loose icing (which is fine for certain recipes) than a thick, rich frosting.  I read one review that said this consistency may be a result of using margerine - however I used butter and got the same thin consistency.  The only only other substitution I made was to use orange extract instead of vanilla.  I think I will keep looking for that perfect cream cheese recipe.
